comment._content: Yes, Stu - lots of our photos have boys in petticoats/apron-type clothes. I'll be adding some from the Congested Districts Board that show the same practice...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: In those days it was usual for children from less well-off families to go about bare-footed during the summer months. It was the ones who still had no shoes during winter that were to be most pitied.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Speaking to someone recently whose 86 year old uncle (born in 1925) had just died. The uncle grew up near Rosslare in Co. Wexford, and had told his nephew that he never forgot that he had been the only boy in his local National School who had shoes going to school. (His parents had a shop and a farm)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Boys generally wore petticoats up to six or seven in those days and we had old photos like that.  Children went barefoot in summertime up to the mid 1940's

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: Where my Mother was from in Killeen; Ballycastle, Co. Mayo, the National School had 2 outhouse's in the back with a wall separating the boys and girls.  The wall ran from the School Building to the Back Wall.  Probably not alot of Out of Wedlock Babies born in Ireland in those days.  My Mother was born in 1904.
